data.text:
@bethsawin @Liminal The cdc covid data tracker coincidentally still looks like last year, and has much more helpful metrics. 

https://t.co/8UHfQhY793

@bethsawin 💯 

I'm still looking at the old CDC maps. Our county just got to an old yellow, which is < 50 cases per 100k, in 7 days. And it's been week over week downward trend. That's so much more useful for evaluating household risk.

@bethsawin I'm in VT, as well.  We've done better than many other places but the safety calculations are still political/economical rather than a systems thinking approach to public health.  Sadly, it's still markets/$ over lives.  We need #SystemLevelChange.  

https://t.co/niW3yJjrec
*masks as in "obfuscates"; not masks as in "put your mask on" lol

@bethsawin This is an excellent take as my partner and I relocate to VT. Went out to dinner last night and got mixed messages on masks... Upon viewing this data, I think we'll be masking up a bit longer.

That feels like an early warning to me, in systems thinking terms. An early warning that could help us swing into action before the situation becomes harder to manage. But the CDC index masks that, and I really hope we don't come to regret it.
One more thing....in Vermont, for 8 of our 10 counties, the trend over the last two weeks is ⬆️ And where there is a ⬇️ trend, the magnitude is smaller than many of the ups. https://t.co/p7pzjYpOos

And, from what I can see only one VT county is over that magic mark of  200, the county in the lower left of this map, maxing out the color scale. 207 new cases per 100,000 people. https://t.co/OADDKFLSnf

But, as with wildfires or rumors or anything else with the potential to grow exponentially, early warning is key. You want to know as the rise starts off, not when knock on consequences of the rise begin to show up.
Hospital capacity matters of course, so it's good to have this indicator. But it's not an *early* indicator. There's a lag of weeks between first infection and hospitalization.
